title: Lab 01
text:
If you havenâ€™t done so already, please download and install R and RStudio. R is the programming language, and RStudio is an integrated development environment that makes using R much more pleasurable. My advice is to always use RStudio and never run code in R itself.
For complete beginners: For those who are completely new to R (or those who want a refresher), I recommend working through an online tutorial.

title: Lab 01
text:
If you havenâ€™t done so already, please download and install R and RStudio. R is the programming language, and RStudio is an integrated development environment that makes using R much more pleasurable. My advice is to always use RStudio and never run code in R itself.
For complete beginners: For those who are completely new to R (or those who want a refresher), I recommend working through an online tutorial.

title: Lab 01
text:
Warm-up: The Iris Dataset
The most important aspects of R to focus on for this module are Basic plotting and Manipulation of matrices and data frames. Letâ€™s look at the built-in iris dataset.

Exercise 1
Can you plot the sepal length against the sepal width?

library(ggplot2)

Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.3

ggplot(iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_minimal()








Data Manipulation
Tasks: Select the column of the iris data that contains sepal length.

Select only the rows for species setosa.
There are several ways to do basic data manipulation in R. You can use base R commands or the dplyr commands (part of tidyverse).

 library(dplyr)
# Selecting and Filtering
iris |> 
  filter(Species == 'setosa') |> 
  summarise(mean_petal = mean(Petal.Length))

title: Lab 01
text:
Matrix Operations
Letâ€™s extract the four numerical columns and store them as a matrix \(X\).
X <- as.matrix(iris[,1:4])
D <- diag(1:4) # Diagonal matrix
X_weighted <- X %*% D
head(X_weighted)

title: Lab 01
text:
Sample Statistics
Calculate the sample mean, covariance, and correlation for the following student data.
Ex1 <- data.frame(
  Student = LETTERS[1:5],
  P = c(41, 72, 46, 77, 59),
  S = c(63, 82, 38, 57, 85)
)

colMeans(Ex1[, 2:3])
cov(Ex1[, 2:3])

title: Lab 01
text:
Multivariate Normal Distribution
Generate 100 samples from the multivariate normal distribution with \(\mu = (1, 0)^T\) and \(\Sigma = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}\).
library(mvtnorm)
mu <- c(1, 0)
Sigma <- matrix(c(2, 1, 1, 2), nr=2)
set.seed(843)
X_mvn <- rmvnorm(n=100, mean=mu, sigma=Sigma)
plot(X_mvn, main="Synthetic MVN Samples")

title: STT843: Multivariate Data Analysis
text: Welcome to the course website for STT843 This course provides an introduction to the statistical analysis of multivariate data, focusing on both theoretical foundations and practical applications in R.

title: STT843: Multivariate Data Analysis
text:
ğŸ› ï¸ Software Requirements
We will be using R and RStudio for all computations. Please ensure you have the following installed:
1. [R (version 4.3+)](https://cran.r-project.org/)
2. [RStudio Desktop](https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/)
3. [Quarto CLI](https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/)
